Award.AwardTitle: Faunistic Survey of the Dynastinae (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae) of Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project studies the dynastine scarab beetles of Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize. It will provide the first extensive documentation of the taxonomic, geographic, and temporal distribution of dynastines in these countries and will become the first study to provide a means to identify all species of this subfamily. Collections in museums in the United States and the study area will be surveyed to gather data associated with those specimens, and extensive collecting will be conducted to acquire new information and most likely many new species. Authoritatively identified collections will be established at institutions in all three countries. The research will contribute to the development of computer programs for organizing and accessing knowledge about insects and this will provide a resource for future biotic surveys. Results will include an illustrated monograph on the Dynastinae of Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize that includes an introduction to the three countries, identification keys for all species, and detailed species accounts (all in English and Spanish).

Taxonomic monographs are cornerstones of comparative biology. Users of this monograph will include scientists working with dynastines, ecologists, and park and reserve managers needing to know the faunal composition of areas they manage. The study area is biologically rich, but it is also an area of increasingly intense land use where pristine areas are succumbing to development. The first step in managing resources in developing countries is identifying the fauna.. Additional products of this project will be the training of a PhD student and training curators and students in the study area that will in turn promote conservation and use of their research collections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Taxonomy is the science that discovers, classifies, and documents organisms. It is foundational to biodiversity science and rests on the discovery and accurate identification of  species that compose ecosystems. In this project, we collected in the field and surveyed the dynastine scarab beetles in research collections in the USA, Canada, Mexico, and Guatemala to gather data on spatial and temporal distributions, life history, and habitat information associated with the specimens. We augmented scientific infrastructure by authoritatively identifying and curating these collections to world class standards and serving all the data (67,390 specimens) on the web. We published a 661 page monograph containing all known information about the charismatic subfamily Dynastinae in the study area. All species can now be identified using bilingual keys and associated images. We published 30 papers citing this grant, described 24 new species, recorded numerous new country records, and created a huge database. A project overview is at Team Scarab website: http://museum.unl.edu/research/entomology/Mexico-Survey/home.html.

We trained one female M.S. and one minority Ph.D. student in biodiversity science and each is now on that career path. We collaborated with scientists and students at institutions in Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize so that they become better versed in faunistic surveys, modern methods of care of research collections, and enhanced inquiry into the diversity and value of the biota of their own countries. Workshops on dynastine scarabs were given to participants in Belize, Guatemala, Mexico, Peru, Dominica, and Jamaica. Presentations or our research at national and international meetings, journal articles, and a scarab symposium at The Natural History Museum (London) were completed.  Collaborator Cano implemented a system of parataxonomists (lay people) in Guatemala for four years who assisted with collecting and data gathering.

We provided educational outreach about biodiversity to K-12 students, the public, and groups underrepresented in science in Mexico, Guatemala, Belize, and the USA via school visits, tours of research collections, popular articles, websites, and newspaper articles, thus empowering students to be involved with conservation and science endeavors. Principal outreach websites were Beetle Mania at the University of Nebraska State Museum (http://museum.unl.edu/research/entomology/ Mexico-Survey/education/beetle/ mania.html) and the Spanish/English website “Scarabs for Kids”  http://museum.unl.edu/research/entomology/Scarabs-for-Kids/ home.html).

However, we still do not  know the composition of the plants and animals that inhabit planet Earth. If we seek to understand and manipulate intricate biological systems in order to solve societal problems, then an understanding of biodiversity is critical to that goal.
